Let me clarify.  Buckland's code DOES reevaluate genomes that have already =
been evaluated.  For my application, I prevent this to save simulation time=
.  I understand the point in the referenced message.

Thanks

Raymond

--- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, "ddambroeplex" <ddambro84@...> wrote:
>
> I'm not =
familiar with the workings of Buckland's code, so there may be some reason =
why what you mention won't work there.  However, in general, as long as you=
r domain is deterministic and your fitness function is static, there is not=
hing wrong with only updating the new genomes' fitness values.   However, t=
here are many situations where you would want to reevaluate all genomes dur=
ing every generation.  This post: http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/m=
essage/4956 contains an example of one, basically you should reevaluate eve=
ryone if there is any chance that you will get a different fitness value by=
 doing so.
> 
> David D'Ambrosio
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "rvonwah=
lde" <rvonwahlde@> wrote:
> >
> > In Bucklands Windows NEAT, the fittest ge=
nomes in each species are kept from the previous generation (elitism). Thes=
e are not mutated.  Therefore, is it correct that there should be no reason=
 to update their fitness scores?
> > 
> > My NEAT application uses the neur=
al nets in a simulation.  An unmutated neural net will return the same outp=
ut and therefore fitness each time.
> > 
> > To save run time, I only updat=
e newly mutated or crossovered genomes.
> >
>
